thread.title: In Washington, a medical marijuana dispensary hides in plain sight
thread.title_full: In Washington, a medical marijuana dispensary hides in plain sight

author: Rema Rahman
title: In Washington, a medical marijuana dispensary hides in plain sight
text:
Public hearing on cannabis bills set for Monday (Rema Rahman) 
Maryland lawmakers passed a similar rule to create public and operation zones. Displays of medical marijuana are also not allowed to be visible and not even patients are allowed to touch the product until packaged. 
Metropolitan Wellness Center General Manager Vanessa West has been in the medical cannabis business for the last decade. She started out in San Diego, where she says the typical patients were Caucasians in their 20s. 
In Washington's south east neighborhood, the most patients are African Americans in their 40s. 
Marijuana laws have gotten stricter as they've made their way toward the Atlantic, West said. There's also the stigma of pot users and the criminal repercussions of using and possessing the drug that isn't apparent there. Medical cannabis growing operation Courtesy photo / HANDOUT The outside of a medical cannabis growing operation run by GTI in Rock Island, Il. The group intends to open a similar business in Hagerstown, Md. now that the state is allowing the growing, processing and dispensing of medical marijuana. - Original Credit: The outside of a medical cannabis growing operation run by GTI in Rock Island, Il. The group intends to open a similar business in Hagerstown, Md. now that the state is allowing the growing, processing and dispensing of medical marijuana. - Original Credit: (Courtesy photo / HANDOUT) 
"Cannabis is just a way of life — no one cares," West said of the California attitude on marijuana. "Here, it's a different story. If you are a pot smoker, you are still viewed as being lazy, or a criminal or someone who doesn't have aspirations." 
The wellness center serves about one-third of the nearly 4,000 patients registered in the district's medical marijuana program. 
Behind the locked door in the lobby, the center serves medical marijuana from smokable buds to oils and a raw vegan cold-pressed juice. That's the only thing available in edible form in the district. Edible marijuana will not be allowed in Maryland. 
While Anne Arundel County will be debating measures to restrict medical marijuana operations, other Maryland jurisdictions are welcoming the economic investment. 
In Washington County, Green Thumb Industries, or GTI, received unanimous approval from the local planning commission for a growing and processing operation outside Hagerstown. 
The company, which operates a 45,000 square-foot facility in Rock Island, Il., wants to develop a 20-acre parcel in western Maryland. GTI partners Sterling Crockett and Ben Kovler told The Capital they are putting a $12 million investment into the local economy, which includes acquiring land, the building labor and equipment. 
While the investment might be local, all application fees and yearly license renewal fees — which can be more than $100,000 — is sent to the state. 
While the focus for GTI is on cultivation, they are also considering where they could put a dispensary and "figure out where we're welcomed," Kovler said. 
For West, the dispensary's undisclosed location works for and against them. 
"No one knows we're here," she said. 
Still, along with the privacy, people shouldn't be ashamed for finding relief in what they are selling, she said.
